title: Social-justice warriors can&#039t take the &#039South Park&#039 heat
text:
For almost two decades, “South Park” has lambasted . . . every thing. The cartoon’s raw satire offends left, right and center all races and religions — and atheists, also. But some are just too dense to get it.
This week’s season premiere slapped “social-justice warriors” — extremists out to police each and every word for bias.
“PC Principal” requires over the school attended by Kyle, Stan, Kenny and Cartman, the four kids at the show’s heart.
Kyle gets two weeks’ detention for daring to inform a fourth-grader, “I don’t assume Caitlyn Jenner is a hero” — which the principal calls “transphobic and bigoted hate speech.”
Later, Pc Principal beats Cartman inside an inch of his life for not falling into line.
Enter the “warriors.” Culture web-site Bustle complained the show produced it “seem like a negative factor to strive for right language about transgender issues.”
“Comedian” Peter Coffin spent hours tweeting about the unfairness of it all.
Film critic Bob Chipman whined that creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker have “slowly morphed into the Trump of Television comedy.”
It all proved Parker and Stone proper.
